Mercury.name: Mercury
Mercury.funFact: Mercury has no atmosphere and experiences the most extreme temperature swings in the solar system - from freezing cold to hot enough to melt lead!

Venus.name: Venus
Venus.funFact: Venus rotates backwards compared to most planets and has days longer than its years - one day on Venus equals 243 Earth days!

Earth.name: Earth
Earth.funFact: Earth is the only known planet with liquid water on its surface and the only place in the universe confirmed to harbor life!

Mars.name: Mars
Mars.funFact: Mars has the largest volcano in the solar system - Olympus Mons is three times taller than Mount Everest and as wide as Arizona!

Jupiter.name: Jupiter
Jupiter.funFact: Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a storm that has been raging for over 400 years and is large enough to fit three Earths inside it!

Saturn.name: Saturn
Saturn.funFact: Saturn is less dense than water - if you could find a bathtub big enough, Saturn would actually float!

Uranus.name: Uranus
Uranus.funFact: Uranus rotates on its side at a 98-degree angle, likely due to a massive collision billions of years ago - it literally rolls around the Sun!

Neptune.name: Neptune
Neptune.funFact: Neptune has winds reaching up to 2,100 km/h - the fastest in the solar system, despite being the farthest planet from the Sun!

Sun.name: The Sun
Sun.funFact: The Sun is so massive that it contains 99.86% of all the mass in our solar system, and every second it converts 4 million tons of matter into energy!

Moon.name: The Moon
Moon.funFact: The Moon always shows the same face to Earth due to tidal locking, and it's slowly moving away from us at about 3.8 cm per year!

Phobos.name: Phobos
Phobos.funFact: Phobos orbits Mars so fast that it rises in the west and sets in the east, completing three orbits in a single Martian day!

Deimos.name: Deimos
Deimos.funFact: Deimos is so small and irregularly shaped that if you stood on it, you could literally throw a baseball into orbit around it!

Io.name: Io
Io.funFact: Io is the most volcanically active body in the solar system, with over 400 active volcanoes that can shoot sulfur 500 km into space!

Europa.name: Europa
Europa.funFact: Europa has a subsurface ocean that contains twice as much water as all of Earth's oceans combined, hidden beneath its icy crust!

Ganymede.name: Ganymede
Ganymede.funFact: Ganymede is the largest moon in the solar system - bigger than Mercury - and has its own magnetic field and aurora!

Callisto.name: Callisto
Callisto.funFact: Callisto is the most heavily cratered object in the solar system and may have a subsurface ocean beneath its ancient, battered surface!

Titan.name: Titan
Titan.funFact: Titan has lakes and rivers of liquid methane and ethane, and its thick atmosphere would let you fly with just wings strapped to your arms!

Rhea.name: Rhea
Rhea.funFact: Rhea may have its own ring system, making it potentially the first moon known to have rings around it!

Titania.name: Titania
Titania.funFact: Titania is the largest moon of Uranus and has massive canyon systems that stretch for over 1,000 km across its surface!

Oberon.name: Oberon
Oberon.funFact: Oberon is named after the fairy king from Shakespeare's 'A Midsummer Night's Dream' and has a mysterious dark material covering parts of its crater floors!

Triton.name: Triton
Triton.funFact: Triton is the only large moon that orbits backwards around its planet and has nitrogen geysers that shoot 8 km high into its thin atmosphere!
